Mosquitos are most attracted to carbon dioxide exhalation. The male mosquito is a plant feeder and doesn't feed on blood, also it is the male that you hear buzzing around your head, don't worry the males don't bite. The female must have a blood meal in order to lay their eggs. They feed on birds, reptiles and mammals including humans. Their prey choices depends upon many factors including your genetics, diet, previous diseases and environmental factors. A typical county or parish in the SE US has approximately 60 species of mosquitos all of which have different lifecycles and desired food and blood meal requirements. Mosquitos are disease vectors which can transmit viral and microfilial diseases  within numerous animal species. Most animals such as humans can become reservoirs of these diseases once the disease is contracted and the mosquito is the vector of transmission between animal species and individuals.

My father told me this and I have not been bitten by any bugs other than an occasional spider in years despite the fact that I garden every day when I have a chance!

I take about 1000mg of the vitamin B-1, before I go outside. Apparently the mosquitoes hate the "smell" of B-1 and will not bite you! I notice they will still fly around me,and even occasionally land on me, but none have bitten me. I still kill them, LOL! B-1 is a water soluble vitamin like vitamin C so your body depletes it rather rapidly! If you are going to be outside for more than 5-6 hours you may want to refresh your B-1 by taking a couple of 200-400MG more. I have noticed the mosquitoes do get more aggressive when it rains and towards evening so you want to be sure the B-1 is prevalent in you blood stream and skin cells!

Believe me or not, its up to you. I was skeptical when Dad told me, and ignored him for a decade or two. I wish I hadn't! I haven't been bitten by a gnat, or a mosquito in over a decade now! What makes me laugh is my wife tried it and she found it worked! But she doesn't like taking pills, so everyday she whines about being bitTen just because she took the dogs out, LOL!! Meanwhile, I garden for 5-6 hours, and even more and don't get bitten!!

If you try it and find it works! Share the info!

I don't like the statement "humans may have evolved this trait to smell worse to mosquitoes as an adaptation to avoid the diseases" because it sounds like something our species consciously did. It seems more correct to say that humans that mutated this way were more likely to be able to pass on their genes to offspring, who would then also be more likely to be able to do so. And given how deadly mosquito-borne diseases have been in history and how successful mosquitoes have been in surviving and breeding, it seems inevitable that this has occurred to some extent.

What about the parasite that makes the fish go to swim in shallow waters so that it could be eaten by its next host - a bird. What about the parasite that makes the ant climb to the top of the grass, so that it could be eaten by the sheep which is parasite's second host? There are many examples of parasites altering the behavior of their hosts. What about parasites that transmit their genes by sperm and eggs of the host and they make the host more attractive to the opposite sex, so that it increases the chances the host will have sex and thus transmit its own genes by helping the host transmit his genes? Oh, wait those parasites joined our genome and now are part of us. Parasites are the real deal!

One thing I really dislike about this video is the question at the end: "do you think humans may have evolved this trait [...] or is it just an accident...?"
Which implies that evolution is not just the result of random circumstances. Evolution is not directed, it's not a reactive process. There are random mutations happening all the time, and whatever sticks, sticks. If an individual with a certain random mutation is more likely to survive then the mutation is more likely to spread, that's it.
It's not like any organism is actively developing a genetic mutation as a reaction to a threat.

Genetic attractiveness or protectedness from mosquitoes might not be the only evolutionary change in humans to defend against them. Our ability to hear their high pitched flight, along with our generally instinctual fear of them and proclivity for fight or flight as a means of dealing with them, may indicate that those of the ancient humans who DIDN'T react to the proximity of mosquitoes subsequently died off from malaria and other mosquito-borne pathogens. Therefore, even without genetic mosquito repellent, some humans managed to survive with behavioral genetics instead.

I think about things a lot, and I feel like my old understanding of evolution was slightly off thinking it was more of an active change to improve, but now seems more obvious that it's just our definition of the results of a natural process. Properties of things are carried on with genetics or construction, the good properties do well and the less good properties don't do as well. We can observe Malaria transmission working better by making the host more attractive to the transmitter, but not in a way where Malaria was consciously making that decision. That mutation/property of Malaria just happens to work well so that specific trait will be more prevalent as it performs better, increasing its numbers.

Interesting... As is my experience with mosquitos. About 5 years ago, I moved to a friend's property just inside the inner loop a couple of miles from the center of Houston, Texas. While waiting for the building of a Container home, I lived in tents in the backyard. Eager to visit, my friend's dogs would tear holes in the sides. The available bathroom was in a building across the yard. Not compulsive about clothes and alone on the property, I wore little more than speedos. For an occasional bug repellent, I used a self-formulated spray based on Red Cedar oil, the same wood used for wool storage boxes. At night as I would go to the bathroom, I was a walking 6-foot mosquito salad bar. I just put up with the bites. I did learn as their wings would beat against my skin that mosquitos are a bit clumsy at landing. The itching was expected. But strangely, after a couple of weeks, the itching went away. I had become immune to the three or four mosquito varieties in the yard. But that surprise was eclipsed by what happened within a couple of weeks. While watching TV, my left forearm felt a little fuzzy so I took my right hand to wipe away whatever the fuzz was. To my surprise, my left arm was fuzzy from the elbow to the wrist. Pausing to look, I discovered that I was brushing away a dozen dead mosquitos. Looking closely, I saw another half dozen still stuck to my arm. They were held in place by their Proboscis still planted in my skin. The only explanation that I have for this is that some part of the immunity I developed to their saliva became a rapid deadly poison to them. As I told this story to friends, one who spent much of her time outside replied that she experiences the same thing.

I've read there's quite a bit of controversy about those private companies that do DNA tests, for privacy reasons.
It was found out that not only the contract you sign with them allows for them to use your data freely, but it also that they actually sell that data to other companies, for example farmaceutical ones, for profit.
First of all, this is kind of amoral because they profit over data you provide, but you don't get a share of it. In fact, you pay them yourself. Basically, you become a test subject but you pay for it, when it should be the other way around.
Secondarily, it's also extremely concerning because your DNA is extremely sensible data and shouldn't circulate freely. It should be used for the sole purpose you requested, anonymously, and then the data should be destroyed.

Like a moth to a flame. However, I do wonder, how much of "are you a mosquito attractant" is subjective. I mean you are asking people to report that. There are many factors that would make one more prone to feeling like they are bitten by mosquitoes more often than others. For example, allergy. Some people who are bitten may not feel the bite at all, others may feel them, but aren't overly bothered by them so they dismiss the event. Still others like myself, may have some allergy to them, and being bitten is painful, and causes massive local redness and swelling. The bites puff up and swell to the point they become open sores. Borrowing some data from other videos, the more significant an event, the longer the event feels in your head. The more you subjectively suffer from being bitten by a mosquito, the more likely you are going to remember the event. Similarly, if someone believes themselves to be an "attractor" then any amount of mosquito activity would give them confirmation bias. Sorta like seeing a yellow car, when you're thinking of a yellow car.

These factors may make a person more or less likely to report being an "attractant" while the number of actual mosquito bites may be exactly the same as someone who reports NOT being an attractant. That and the question is subjective. When you are out in the woods what is "a lot" of mosquito bites? One? Two? A hundred? You also need to consider environmental factors with these reports, such as, do you live in the city, the country? Is the gene being examined one that makes someone more likely to enjoy the out doors and therefore they get bitten more often? Is it more likely to make them "successful" and therefore live in a city where the mosquito population is controlled, either directly or indirectly. Does it make them prone to liking water sports and therefore live near bodies of water that mosquitoes breed in? I mean the list is legitimately infinite. Love the content.

I come from the United Kingdom now living in America the past 6 years plus. I was raised predominantly right on the edge of the English forest. We had lakes and miles of endless forestry. I never got bitten by any mosquitoes. After which over the years I lived in various regions of England. I enjoyed many camping and caravanning 'RV' holidays all over the UK and never suffered from mosquito bites. Over the years I became a globe trotter and have travelled to most parts of Europe many times, even to Russia and never had a mosquito bite. I have also been to regions of Brazil, and also several other South American countries mostly cities or coastal regions and never got bitten by mosquitoes. I have been to 13 States in America from NY to CA across to FL and all across most Southern States, and even in Florida which is known for mosquitoes, I never once got bitten. But, since coming to TX for some crazy reason I have become a magnet to the mosquitoes here so much so that, I can no-longer enjoy enjoy the luxury of even sitting out in the garden without being smothered in terrible mosquito bites that each Spring/Summer is now a living hell! Our entire lives now revolve around mosquitoes that we cannot open a window, even with bug screens the smaller mosquitoes get through. To even open the front or back door we have to do this fast otherwise they will get into the house. We have large fans blowing each time we open the garage door. To have to spend your summers which is supposed to be enjoyable, covered in clothing from neck to toe, unable to wear a summer dress, or shorts and a crop top, not unless I cover myself in repellent which I hate, is just a horrible way to have to live. Gone are the days when over in the UK we all use to have the patio doors open and all the windows open during summer, enjoying the garden with friends and family and never having to deal with anything like mosquitoes. We even had a large pond and water fountains. So imagine trying to sunbathe in our garden here in TX would be a living hell with these mosquitoes, it just couldn't be done. We have planted herbs, citronella, regularly get the grounds sprayed, used foggers, burned oils lamps, ensured there is no foliage or sitting water,, but nothing seems to work! We cannot even grow the flowers we wanted. I cannot even wear perfume anymore If anyone is reading this and had the same experience as me and could help me solve the mystery of what the heck is going on here?, Please I would love to hear from you.

For the evolutionary question, the best test would be to look at people who live in and have a long family history (centuries/millennia) in an area that malaria is very common. Statistically, those with an ancestry that had the repellant genes should be far more common, as it's survival of the fittest (those who attract more mosquitos would die off younger and have less potential children). If those areas don't show a strong bias towards the current generation with long ancestry in the region with the genetics dissuading mosquito bites, then it clearly isn't an evolutionary thing. For those with ancestry from regions with low mosquito populations and no indigenous malaria, there shouldn't be any notable difference between the groups

3:55 That is such an interesting graph, i wished he explained it more:
1. What is "relative attraction"? Is it normalised to a control, or is it head to head analysis with a twin in A vs their sibling in B?
2. Why is the axis cropped at 55% 😐
3. Shouldn't there be half below 50% assuming normal distribution?
4. The chart shows that if you are any type of twin, you are WAAYYYY more attractive to mosquitoes than the control
5. WTF is that line? Is it linear regression? Or is it the expected maximum genetic correlation i.e. if genes were the sole determinant, then the black dots would be closer to the line.
6. In that case shouldn't they have done a chi² or ANOVAR rather than a scatter plot as I don't know if there is a statistical difference between identical and fraternal twins based on how far they spread away from the dotted line
7. Why are all the dots in the top right rather than distributed along the line. We would expect some twins to be repulsive compared to the control comparator and therefore be in the lower left of the graph. or at the very least, distributed evenly along the dotted line

TL;DR: the graph doesn't show any genetic basis, rather that 85-100% of mosquitoes would rather bite someone who is a twin rather than a control.

If you eat MEAT you will attract mosquitoes!    I remember, gathering with around a dozen other people for a scuba diving trip.  We all waited in a big circle, talking and shooting the breeze.  It was about 7AM and just getting light.  Then we noticed that everyone in the group was going crazy slapping themselves, slapping their arms, legs, neck, chest, anywhere their skin was exposed.  And they all started complaining about being chomped on but the pesky things.  But we stood there and never received a single bite!   We were both vegetarians and not the least enticing to those ravenous mosquitoes!   I go years and years without ever being bitten by mosquitoes.   Maybe in five or six years, I might get one mosquito bite, a very rare event for sure!    Eating meat causes your body odor to become extremely enticing to those little vampires, and we vegetarians are living examples of what I'm talking about.  We go everywhere outside, with no mosquito repellent ever, because our vegetarian bodies are a natural mosquito repellent.  So if you have serious mosquito biting issues, consider skipping the animal products...plus you will feel and look much better!   When I became a vegetarian, over 40 years ago, I weighed 155 pounds.  I'm 5'2" and that was way too much!   It took about 8 or 9 months to come down to 105 pounds, which I've maintained all these years.   Diets don't work, because after the diet, people return to their old eating habits and end up gaining it all back, plus some...and I know that personally!   It must be a life-change or else you will end up always being overweight and unhappy.   There are thousands of delicious veggie meals to discover on the net, plus a plethora of books at the library and book store.  Being a vegetarian does not mean only eating bowls of vegetables.   Say, if you went to a Thanksgiving dinner, and there were 25 dishes on the table, you can have everything except the turkey...and even the dressing if it's prepared without turkey.  Do you think you'd walk away from that dinner hungry?   Of course not!   Plus, almost all restaurants now serve very delicious vegetarian dishes, and you can have Italian, Mexican and Chinese, etc., etc. so there is no excuse to feel deprived by giving up the flesh pots!   So, anyway, after all the lab testing, trying to figure out who gets mosquito bitten, it all boils down to your diet.  And as long as you eat meat, you will remain a banquet for those hungry biting, little monsters.   BTW...if you do go vegetarian, it will take a few months before you become repulsive to mosquitoes, as it takes while for all the meat odors to leave your body.  So do be patient, and you will eventually be able to stay outside in perfect peace, while others are being driven crazy and eaten alive...it's your choice!        For Big Truth!    kristi

An incredible thing happened recently in our never-ending battle against mosquitos. Scientists had released something like a million genetically adapted females into a particularly dangerous species of mosquito (there are thousands of species, but only a few dozen which bite us.). The idea being that these females would breed, and then their offspring would be sterile. (it could also be that that second generation was still fertile, but the third generation was sterile, I forget which. I think it was the third generation that was sterile. )

This all seemed to work pretty well, they were seeing huge numbers of these sterile mosquitos. But within a **single generation**, the mosquitos evolved a counter mechanism against it and overcame the sterility completely. 😮

ANY time anyone asks "did spieces X develop property Y to achieve Z or was it an accident"... Why are humans not capable of getting this? Any genetic change resulting in a new property is by accident. If it's beneficial to have that property you will see it prevail compared to individuals who don't have it. Because of natural selection. It's very simple. So the answer is YES it was an accident and since it's beneficial you see it in more and more people. But in many places there aren't so many mosquitoes with diseases so you can procreate without the property just fine and that is why not everybody has them.

Think about the Toxoplasma Gondi. That parasite actually modified the behavior of the animal that it infects(rats, cats, humans) so they(the hosts) go into a cycle of predation that ensure the propagation of that parasite. Humans genearally aren't that good at helping the parasite as much as rats and cats do, but the parasite modified the behavior of humans to take risks that kill them(speeding motorcyclists) which in theory can infect a big cat that eats the human and then the cat's poop infects other humans or other cats that accidentally ingest the poop. This works pretty well with domestic cats and rats. Rats that have toxoplasmosis lose their fear of cats or become attracted to cat smell/cat urine where it end up getting killed and eaten by cats which in effect infect that cat. Then the cat poops and the cycle continues for the Toxoplasma gondi. Interesting stuff.

Mosquito food source is actually leaves from trees, plants and shrubs. They only take our blood to produce their eggs as mentioned in the video. This is why mosquito pest controllers spray plants trees and shrubs. Once the pesticide dries and settles into the plant and onto the leaves, the mosquito begins to feed on those plants. Hence taking away their ability to produce eggs. Once that ability is gone, mosquitoes no longer have use for blood so they don’t bite. It lasts 2-4 weeks in between treatments. Mosquitoes don’t fly any higher than 10 ft, and hop plant to plant using it as cover looking for you as they can only smell you. They are nearly blind.

I am one of those people, but it worked out for the better. As a kid I'd spend my days river fishing with my friends, building forts, damns, rafting, basically every day we were at the river doing something. I'd go home covered in bites; Big, itchy bites that sometimes would leave a bruise they were so big. and stinging nettles (Still not immune to them. They suck.) No exaggeration, 100's of bites per day. Now, for the last thirty years  or so I am completely immune, not just to mosquitos, but deer flies, black flies, Bee's and spiders. I am still the main guy they attack to the point where people notice and ask me how I stand it; I tell them they still get in my nose and eyes due to the massive swarm that is always focused on me more than others, and how that can be a pain, but then I show them that I have no visible bites or itches. If a bee or hornet, wasp, gets me it leaves no mark and stings for nowhere near as long as it would take me to say "Hey, just got stung"! I've often wondered if there was a way scientists could use my blood to give more people this immunity. I've also considered hiring myself out for gatherings as I would keep most of the bugs from bothering others.

I  don't think anecdotes about attractiveness are very useful without considering sensitivity to the bites. My wife complains that mosquitos go right for her and avoid me, but that isn't true. What is true is that when she gets bitten she gets a large itchy welt and when I get bitten there is little or no reaction - no itch or swelling. The Y-tube tests avoids this problem, but whenever people report how attractive they are to mosquitos they really are reporting the bites they notice, which are those with symptoms.

So, you think your job sucks.

Believe it or not, here in Florida, State Laws require certain government employees to have mosquitoes bite them and suck their blood multiple times per day, 5 days a week.

Florida State Statutory Laws require employees/ inspectors to stand still and count how many mosquitoes land on their arm (bite them) during a minutes time period…they call it a “landing rate”.

Though threshold numbers very from county to county in Florida, statute laws requires documented “landing rate” count numbers to exceeded a certain number before they can apply a chemical spray treatment to reduce the mosquito populations… something like more that 12 mosquitoes landing on their arm during the 60 second time period.

Pretty sure these people are under paid, because certain areas of the state regularly experience 100-400 landings per minute.

The mind boggling thing here is that mosquito populations can get so bad at times, that it has cause whole beards of cattle to die… not due to blood loss, but from asphyxiation and not being able to breathe.

Now all of this sounds like a horrible job, but it gets even worse when you consider that these same employees are also prohibited from wearI have cologn or perfume (as well as a laundry list of other such things mentioned in the videothat could potentially skew the landing rate results).

So, in addition to getting sucked on by mosquitoes all day long, these poor employees are also forced to stink to high heaven and have poor hygiene.. as Florida is the poster child for one needing to use deodorant due to sweltering oppressive summer heat.

Knowing all of this helps put things into perspective… and also helps recalibrate what having a bad day at work actually looks like.

So, even though your job may suck at times, I am sure it doesn’t include any lawfully required bloodletting.

DNA tests are great! My dad always told me about rumours involving an African bloodline, so we got my 97 year old Oma to send in her spit. It turns out that she has 1% DNA from Togo and 1% from Benin which proved the stories to be true. We learned that it takes seven generations to remove a certain strain of DNA so my dad was able to trace our African bloodline to a slave who travelled from Africa to Suriname and then to the Netherlands. It makes me sad to know my ancestors may have been involved with the slave trade, however having that DNA in my family tree makes me think my 9x great Opa fell in love and started a family with someone he liberated from slavery! Either way I’m glad to know my roots 👍🏼

Back in the day when I went backpacking, mosquitos where a problem and here is how I dealt with it including commercial chemicals that can be applied to clothing and skin.

Mosquitos are most active in the morning and at dawn.
So keeping this in mind for the evening when we would all be eating dinner and later just sitting around talking before we started our campfire for the evening.

I would not eat anything sweet for dinner because it makes your skin and breath more attractive to mosquitos.
No fruit, no candy, no hot chocolate with marshmallows, no honey, no granola bar...

I would chop up some raw garlic and swallow it down with a swig of water.

That in combination with commercial chemicals applied properly, I rarely ever got bitten whilst the guys and gals around me did.

I found out by accident that sweetness of my blood affects if mosquitos will attract to me or other. Before, on regular diet, I was a mosquito-magnet! If we were out in nature I was one of those who was mostly bitten... Mosquitos wouldn't leave me alone! I've tried many different products, mosquito-repellants, UV-lamps, ultrasound, because I like to be in nature and like to go fishing...

But these last 2-3 years I have switched to LCHF diet - don't eat sugar and avoid carbohydrates. My blood is less sweet now, has lower insulin, and I produce ketones... And now it's completely different. I do get bitten sometimes but it's much less than before. And if I'm out with family or friends, mosquitos mostly ignore me and attack the others... If an estimated half of all humans have been killed by mosquito born diseases (even though that estimate might be too high), I feel like it would make sense that some natural selection has occurred. The people who are born with favorable genetics that make them unattractive to mosquitos are less likely to be bitten by mosquitos and therefore less likely to contract malaria. Then, they go on to reproduce while other humans who are unfortunately attractive to mosquitos die of malaria. The evolution of malaria to make its host more attractive to mosquitos further increases the chance of malaria and the subsequent probability that human-mosquito magnets die out. Maybe some level of natural selection has been happening behind the scenes without us noticing! I find this all fascinating!

I take issue with how you frame evolution, as if it's intentional.
The Malaria you speak of has gone through many changes over the ages to become the Malaria it is today. In the competitive environment called reality, there were likely many variants of Malaria which didn't cause their hosts to be more attractive to mosquitos. As soon as a Malaria variant mutated to cause their hosts to be more attractive to mosquitos, that variant would have dominated the competitive landscape, and are now the predominant form.

Random mutation plus natural selection. Not directed.
Will and intent exist at the level of the creature and the social group. It does not exist at the level of a species. There is no "will of all mice" or "intentions of the antelope species", hence there is no direction for evolution.
What I find fascinating is that undirected, distributed process of evolution seems to resemble a very powerful decision tree for a huge NP-complete problem: "explore all options simultaneously". Biology appears to be its own weird kind of quantum computer somehow.

To question whether some humans have evolved traits in order to be less attractive to mosquitos, or if it's an accident that they have that trait, is a fundamental misunderstanding of evolution. EVERY trait that is evolved that helps a species survive is an ACCIDENT. There's no intention, there's no deliberate evolution. Every trait any species has is a random mutation - some help adaptiveness to the environment, such as resistance to mosquitos, and so the individuals possessing it are more successful at survival, other mutations that don't help don't persist.

I used to be bitten about as often as an average person. Until one day I went camping in the Florida everglades where we hit some sort of mosquito storm. All night long we were bitten hundreds or thousands of times. It made us sick to the point of vomiting and we obviously swelled up.

Since then, we have been resistant to mosquito bites. I did not receive a noted bite for about 10 years. Now, 30 years later, I get a handful of bites at the beginning of each season but they leave me alone after that. It may be that I just don't react to the bites, but I do notice that they tend to land on me but immediately fly off. No doubt that there are scents which attract and repel them, but environmental factors are likely to be at least as big of an influencing factor as DNA.

That malaria changes the body chemistry to attract more mosquitos isn't really "phenomenal." Simple natural selection would produce this every single time. It's merely the result of evolution. Those malaria parasites that do this gain a significant advantage and are thus the prevalent parasite. That's really the definition of evolution.

It's like saying, "Wow, how did giraffes figure out growing longer necks would provide them with more food?" They didn't! Just lucky mutations that created longer necks simply ensured the survival of that genetic stock. In hindsight, it looks planned; in reality it's just random changes that result in giving advantage to a species prevail.

Not sure it is even possible, yet since the plasmodium parasites do reproduce sexually at some point in their life cycle, I am guessing it may be worth a shot.  I still believe that the total annihilation of every species of mosquito would be preferable.

I know this may sound harsh to most people but are the mosquitoes really our worst enemy here? Aren't they just doing what we ourselves should have done a long long time ago? Manage our total number globally. Not by killing people of course but by establish some kind of global birth control management in order to keep our own numbers in check?

Since we don't have the wisdom and the inteilligence do establish that then the natural world just try to do it for us in it's own harsh way.

Maybe the worst enemy towards human species are not the mosquitoes but ourselves. We are our own worst enemy. Imagine what would happen to the natural world if we dropped back to 2 or 3 billion globally. No more serious pollution. My thoughts from my experience, your body will try to protect itself, it does not happen instantly but takes time.
If you are bitten by mosquitoes, your body will try to make stuff that they do not like (odors) but these are usually effective for one type or group of mosquitos.
It is in the natural skin oils that your body produces (first line protection) if you wash with soap and water the protection is removed.
If you use only fresh water with no soap to get clean leaving the natural oils on your skin these will/might help you with mosquito protection.
Also different areas have different mosquitos and they might not be affected by the defenses you develop in other areas, as in tropical vs northern tundra vs mountain wet areas mosquitos.
Evolution has given use the ability's to defend ourselves over millions of years, lets not strip it all away with something that was made in someone's bathtub only a couple of years ago.
I think BO is caused by the waste of bacterial action on your skin and feet, removing natural oils is opening the feeding grounds for bacteria also.
Just my 2 cents/scents

Of interest, I am normally attractive to mosquitoes. Several years back, I was receiving intravenous doses of a biological drug (histone deacetylase inhibitor or HDAC). The day after receiving a dose, I flew to El Salvador - which has "Zancudos", a vector of Dengue, Chikungunya and Malaria. I noted several of them land on my skin, remain 1-2 seconds, then fly away without biting. At the airport on the way down, my skin was swabbed by TSA and alarmed for a biological agent. That used to be me. 100 people at a party, 1 person gets bit, it's me. Then I moved to Southern Mexico for a few years. The first 6 months mosquitoes ate me alive. Have you ever gotten a mosquito bite on the sole of your foot? I've had a number of them. Worst spot ever to get bit. You need to use hard sharp things like nails to scratch with. Walking on glass gets appealing. Almost nothing will relieve that itch.
But then one day it stopped. Like completely. And for over a decade I just figured mosquitoes had had enough of me and that they no longer bit me. But later I discovered that's not the case. They still bite me. They bite me as much as they ever did. I just no longer react to it. No welt. No itch. Occasionally feel the little stab of one of those guys first biting me, but otherwise, mosquitoes have become irrelevant to me.
Apparently if you get bitten enough, this can happen (but it's not a guarantee). I will tell you, it's one of the greatest gifts I've had in life. To have gone from the guy who always got bit to the guy who just doesn't care anymore.

Hey Derek, at 10:14, your question on whether humans evolved to smell worse to mosquitoes, well, according to evolution, mutation does not occur in order to survive or adapt to the stress. The mutants that are already present are "selected" by that stress which results in survival and proliferation (survival of the fittest). So in this case, humans who had the mutation (mosquitoes repellers) survived the stress and thus passed on their traits, which is what we now find in the population.

Mosquito CURE. I've been eating 1-2 cloves of raw garlic 4-5 days a week. Since doing this I have NOT been bitten by a mosquito for about 3 years. When I would walk my daughter to school in the morning I would get eaten alive by mosquitoes. I couldn't even bring my kids to the playground in the evenings because the mosquitoes would attack me immediately; I would literally go back home with 5-10 bites. As soon as I started eating the garlic the mosquitoes bites STOPPED !!! Literally. 2 summers ago I went to the park around 11pm and sat on the bench, reading from my cell phone. I immediately noticed there were so many mosquitoes swarming around the front of my phone ( due to the light ), that I had difficulty reading from my phone. I then realized I wasn't even getting bitten, not once. They would land on me, and immediately fly away without biting me. Mosquitoes are repulsed by Garlic, this is why they won't bite you.

This is what to do:

1) Cut of 1 clove of garlic very finely.
2) Let it sit for 15 minutes ( this allows the chemicals in the garlic to mix )
3) Scoop up the garlic with a spoon and swallow it with a glass of water.
4) Do this 4-5 days a week.

Note: Don't chew the garlic or your breath will smell. Only swallow it.

That question about if humans evolved to be less attractive to mosquitoes or if it was an accident had me thinking. Isn’t all evolution a mistake that was favorable to the individual? For example, a mutation where a fish lays way more eggs than another fish of the same species. That was a mistake, there was no intentionality behind it, but it was favorable to that individual. More of the offspring of that individual survive and are likely to have inherited that egg mutation and lay a lot more eggs too. That leads to more of these fish with that mutation so that mutation spreads more.

The same can be said of this attractiveness mutation. It was highly likely to be a mistake (I can’t see how a mutation would be intentional but do explain if I’m missing something) but a highly favorable mutation because you are less likely to contract malaria and die and since you live longer, you have a higher chance of producing offspring who inherit that mutation. So, that’s a long-winded way of saying it’s probably both.

Reminds me of sickle cell anemia in countries throughout Africa. In areas where the malaria parasite is prevalent (due to mosquitoes) the rates of sickle cell anemia increase overtime. This eventually leads to a decrease in malaria outbreaks. The malaria parasites can not attach to the deformed blood cells (sickle cells). This leads to the parasites dying off inside of people with sickle cell anemia. Unfortunately the life expectancy for people with sickle cell anemia is not very high and the complications associated with the disease can be excruciatingly painful. It is sad but interesting that such a negative disease can actually be a genetic advantage.

Wildcard monkey wrench variable worth studying: I’ve always had a gut feeling a key factor in an individual’s perception of his/her attractiveness to mosquitoes might be significantly influenced by the characteristics of their individual physiological reactions to mosquito bites. Ive observed in my own social/familial circles a class of folks who experience frequent sensations of being bitten by mosquitoes, and/or prolonged intense itching, and even uncommonly intense swelling, who coincidentally perceive a high personal level of attractiveness to mosquitoes...while at the same time observing peoples in same party equally beset by, slapping, & smashing swarming mosquitoes (and thus likely feeding the mosquitoes in similar amounts) who experience relatively minimal sensation of being bitten/minimal itching/barely noticeable swelling. They tend to classify themselves as less attractive to mosquitoes, when empirical observation seems to point to the conclusion they are equally as attractive. Takeaway: The physiology of the reaction to the bight may significantly influence the perception of one’s attractiveness to mosquitoes, even though the level of attraction from the mosquitos’ perspectives may potentially not vary at all.

When talking about the evolutionary effects on the mosquito resistant genes, it does makes sense that natural selection would have helped in having higher prevalence of these genes. I mean if mosquito's are such effective killers and mosquito's mostly go to mosquito 'attractive' people, then people with genes that make them more attractive to mosquito's are gonna get stung more and mosquito's are gonna kill more of these people. so this should logically have a decent effect on making it so that mosquito repellent genes get more prevalent.

but this also depends on the country/degree of readily available medical help of course. cause if medication can keep mosquito attracting people alive (when without medical attention they would have died) then natural selection has been bypassed by this.
but as long as people keep dying cause of mosquito's, it seems to make a decent amount of sense to expect a net increase in mosquito resistant genes (with a higher net increase in areas where more people die of mosquito's)

I don't think it actually has anything to do with DNA but instead is related to redox potential. In the case of their proof of DNA being the basis using twins as their example, redox potential would likely be around the same as well for twins and as such could still very likely be the real basis. Higher redox potential translates to a lower chance to be bitten and lower redox potential equates to a higher bite chance. Low redox potential also translates to a lot of other problems and health risks too, so it seems reasonable that mosquitoes could be a byproduct of that as well.
I know from experience that Native Americans are not as prone to being bitten by mosquitoes. I used to have some friends that were Native Americans and they never got bit while I got eaten alive. That could be argued as being a genetic DNA based trait passed on to them, but it could also still be redox potential as that gets passed on through the mother by way of the mitochondrial DNA. So, in a sense, I am saying it isn't DNA based and is instead based on redox potential while at the same time that too has a basis in the DNA so it's kind of both :)
The main difference though is that redox potential isn't as fixed as DNA is. It is possible to increase ones redox potential. It is also possible to lower it too, so that could explain some people phasing back and forth on their attractiveness to mosquitoes. The absolute worst thing for redox potential is Fluoride. This is a fact known in chemistry and has nothing to do with any other claims anyone may make about fluoride, though it's likely those claims are true too. It's bad stuff. So, I would start by avoiding that if you want to increase your redox potential.

Since I don't recall seeing it explained, when they're looking at their DNA test results and Derek is talking about "snips" he means SNPs, or Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms. It basically means that in certain genes, you can have variations in one base pair (one set of paired letters in the genetic code) that slightly change how the gene works. Not enough to make it non-functional, just enough to make it a bit different.

"Did humans evolve to be less attractive to mosquitoes"

That is phrased in a way as to imply it's some sort of intelligently selective process, which I'm sure you know it isn't. Random DNA changes made some people less attractive to mosquitoes. Those people are less likely to die from things like malaria, hence less likely to be taken out of the gene pool. Can't pass on your DNA if you're dead. Hence, people who are bitten less are more likely to propagate those genes in areas where mosquitoes are a mortality risk.

In climates where mosquitoes are less common I'm sure you'd find the native population is far less likely to have those mosquito repellent SNPs because the environment didn't select for those genes.

What's more interesting to me personally is that I've recently realised I no longer hear mosquitoes. I used to hear them when I was younger. The sound mosquitoes make is in a frequency range that adults tend to lose when they age. It makes me wonder if the extended hearing range of children has been selected for as an evolutionary advantage so that kids make it to breeding age to pass on their genes by being annoyed by mosquitoes and killing / avoiding them.

The parasite toxoplasma gondii is a cat and rodent parasite that also can infect humans. In the cat it actually modifies the rodent's brain to make it more apt to do the things that keep the parasite life cycle going. That is, lose its fear of cats, so it can be eaten by a cat and complete its life cycle. It is speculated that it can modify a human host's brain as well. Not that this is intentional, because a human being won't complete the life cycle by being eaten by cats, but it's incidental. It's just what the parasite does. The belief is it can make people to become more risk taking, feel more carefree and fearless about life, money and actual danger.

Dear Derek, sounds like you are making us feel like parasites are being bad on purpose. It could make it harder for people to understand the actual mechanisms of nature. Let's get the science straight. :)

It's not really likely that the malaria parasite decided to evolve in such a way that it makes humans produce more mosquito-attracting-odor. It is more likely that some random set of malaria parasites were initially having some mutation that made humans produce more mosquito-attracting-odor. So these humans got bitten more times than the others, and this specific set of parasites eventually spread much more and much faster than all other sets of parasites. Which eventually died.

I wouldn't see a malicious action from the parasite, more the natural randomness of natural selection. Same with viruses and bacteria. They're not really bad, they're just there and happen to have had mutations in their past that made them survive longer than other less effective organisms that didn't make it until today. Since we only see the winner, it might be tempting to argue that they deserve to be here. But the thing is that they just happen to be here today, but they didn't really plan to survive. They just survived.

On the question of whether "Humans evolved this trait to be less attractive to mosquitos," of course the question is ill-formed. If more Humans now carry these traits than did Humans in past generations, it is precisely because those who already had such traits were the ones most likely to avoid mosquito-borne illnesses leading to death (or impotence). Indeed, we should always expect the survivors of any environmental stressor to carry on the traits that made them successful in the first place. That is the thing about evolution. Yes, some of these traits may just be epigenetic (e.g., certain food preferences within a culture) but we still rely very much on death —the Great Editor— to determine which traits proliferate and which traits diminish.

You CAN get access to the mosquito attractiveness test.  Just not directly from 23andMe.  They give you access to download the raw SNP data.  Do that, then there is software freely available online that will give you TONS more information based upon all of the various studies that have come out.  Obviously be careful and investigate this information, but it can tell you far more than 23andMe is permitted to state officially.  Ancestry.coms DNA test gives you much less information from the company itself, but provides more SNPs with more coverage and the raw data you get from them is more useful for finding out more stuff using online resources.  At least, that is what I found when I investigated this stuff a couple months ago.

I was taken aback by the question regarding whether or not we evolved this anti-mosquito trait. The way in which the question was framed was as if to suggest that either A) Humans willfully evolved this trait as a response to the dangers that mosquitoes represent, or B) that it was merely a happy accident. This represents a fundamental lack of understanding regarding how evolution works. The answer to the question is most likely "both are true", at least partially with regards to the first option.

The way it works is that the "happy accidents" occur in some portion of the population naturally and at random. Over time as children that are more and more appealing to mosquitoes are infected and ultimately fail to achieve breeding age, fewer and fewer of those traits are passed on to subsequent generations and thus, those that are unappealing to mosquitoes gain a distinct advantage in terms of successfully breeding and passing along the genes.

The question should never be posed as if to suggest that an adaptation was a response to a threat, as it almost certainly never works that way. Some adaptations can grant advantages to one creature over another in a given environment which then gives them a greater advantage in mate selection, and ultimately reproducing. To ask "Did we evolve this trait in response to this event" implies that at some level in our biology resides an intelligence that recognizes a threat and decides "Right! Something needs to be done about this!". Perhaps this is a pedantic argument, but when it comes to evolutionary biology, the small details are the bigger picture.

I love Veritasium, but I have to ask how all the more obvious factors are eliminated? As in - are mosquitoes more attracted to Healthy Men vs. less robust women, how do we know that they don't sense pheromones or host bacteria that attract mosquitoes over less corpulent hosts? Women often bath more, wear perfume, use hair care products, there are so many variables that would appear to seriously compromise the speculation that specific genes are responsible. That's like saying having a Y chromosome makes you more attractive to mosquitoes when in fact it might just be that men, who are historically (and evolutionarily) more: out doors, found slaughtered in battle fields, the ones out hunting in the tropics, further from fire, smellier, etc, are preferred to females or certain phenotypes. Seems like there are myriad variables that could discredit or support this conjecture. Were there any experiments run with animal subjects removing or mutating those genes? Just because they found a consensus of data that supports their hypothesis doesn't verify its validity. Correlation doesn't not prove causation. I hate to be pedantic here...but I am a Molecular Biologist and I need sufficient proof over hearsay.

BTW, the two variables in the question you pose at the end about evolution are actually the same. There is no sentient, conscious hand behind natural selection. Our bodies didn't decide to mutate in response to mosquitoes. A random mutation happened and that person or persons were maybe slightly more likely to survive mosquito borne disease than their peers without the mutation. Because of this slight advantage it would have been ever so slightly more likely that they would survive long enough to have children and pass along this mutation. And then the cycle continues. Over time, if the mutation is important enough it will become more and more prevalent in the gene pool.

Imagine the sound of a mosquito in the bedroom at night when the light is turned off and you want to sleep. Can you think of anything more annoying?

That sound isn't only a constant tone, it has slight variations when the mosquito flies around. It is a distinct pattern that is easily recognizable even when you are almost sleeping. If that sound is present, you wake up, take one of your house shoes and prepare yourself to flatten that evil insect. It's already two o'clock in the morning, you search the mosquito but in the moment the light was switched on, it landed somewhere and doesn't move anymore. You think you could find it with a moving light source to make the shadow it may cast move around a bit but all tries to find that insect have failed. You put the house shoe back on the floor, switch the light off and shortly after that you hear it again. You pull the blanket over the head and then the feet stick out and you are getting really annoyed and angry and you try kill it again and again. It is already three o'clock morning and you have no chance to sleep. This is pure horror.
